dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, I was just reading this Forbes piece, and it sounds like there's some big news about cleaning up our oceans?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, I was just reading this Forbes piece, and it sounds like there's some big news about cleaning up our oceans?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, for real! It's about Ocean Cleanup, you know, the nonprofit? They just deployed their new floating boom system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, for real! It's about Ocean Cleanup, you know, the nonprofit? They just deployed their new floating boom system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system was deployed on Saturday from San Francisco Bay and will undergo several weeks of testing before being hauled into action. The system was designed by the nonprofit Ocean Cleanup, which was founded in 2013 by 18-year-old Dutch inventor Boyan Slat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, right, the one from San Francisco Bay? I remember hearing about that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, right, the one from San Francisco Bay? I remember hearing about that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system was deployed on Saturday from San Francisco Bay and will undergo several weeks of testing before being hauled into action.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It went out on Saturday. It's gonna be undergoing several weeks of testing, uh, before it's hauled into full action.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It went out on Saturday. It's gonna be undergoing several weeks of testing, uh, before it's hauled into full action.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom system was deployed on Saturday from San Francisco Bay and will undergo several weeks of testing before being hauled into action.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, this whole Ocean Cleanup thing... wasn't it started by some really young inventor?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, this whole Ocean Cleanup thing... wasn't it started by some really young inventor?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Boyan Slat. He was, like, eighteen back in 2013 when he founded it. Pretty incredible, honestly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, Boyan Slat. He was, like, eighteen back in twenty thirteen when he founded it. Pretty incredible, honestly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The system was designed by the nonprofit Ocean Cleanup, which was founded in 2013 by 18-year-old Dutch inventor Boyan Slat.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wild. So, what's the big ambition here? What are they hoping to achieve with this system?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wild. So, what's the big ambition here? What are they hoping to achieve with this system?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the mission is to rid the world's oceans of plastic, right? And with, um, dozens more of these booms, they estimate they could clean up half of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch within five years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the mission is to rid the world's oceans of plastic, right? And with, um, dozens more of these booms, they estimate they could clean up half of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch within five years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Their mission is to develop advanced technologies to rid the worlds oceans of plastic. The floating boom system, with the help of dozens of more booms, is estimated to clean up half of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch within the first five years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Half? Wow. That garbage patch is absolutely massive, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Half? Wow. That garbage patch is absolutely massive, isn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is! It's, like, 1.6 million square kilometers, 1.8 trillion pieces of debris. You can actually see it from space.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is! It's, like, one point six million square kilometers, one point eight trillion pieces of debris. You can actually see it from space.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The garbage patch is so large, it is easily detectable from space via satellites and covers roughly 1.6 million square kilometers and 1.8 trillion pieces of debris.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's just... mind-boggling. So, how does the system actually work once it's out there?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's just... mind-boggling. So, how does the system actually work once it's out there?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's a floating boom, and it, uh, drifts with the currents, creating this U-shaped formation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's a floating boom, and it, uh, drifts with the currents, creating this U-shaped formation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The floating boom drifts along with the local currents, creating a U-shaped formation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] And that's where the trash collects?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that's where the trash collects?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. It has, like, ten feet of netting below it to collect smaller fragments. The idea is that fish can swim beneath it, so it's only collecting trash.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. It has, like, ten feet of netting below it to collect smaller fragments. The idea is that fish can swim beneath it, so it's only collecting trash.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the boom floats, it collects trash in the U shaped system, which has 10 feet of netting below it to collect smaller fragments of plastic. The idea is that the 10 feet of netting is not deep enough that fish can't swim below it, with the hope that the boom will collect trash and not fish.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's smart. But is it, um, totally proven yet in the open ocean?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's smart. But is it, um, totally proven yet in the open ocean?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not entirely, no. It's ambitious, and the technology's still new, but they are, like, the closest thing we have to a solution on this scale.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not entirely, no. It's ambitious, and the technology's still new, but they are, like, the closest thing we have to a solution on this scale.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the organization has ambitious plans and the technology still remains unproven in the open ocean, they are the closest to a solution to cleaning up the garbage patch we have. No other company has a deployable system able to clean up the garbage patch on this scale.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And I heard they've got some pretty big names backing them, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And I heard they've got some pretty big names backing them, too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, Peter Thiel from PayPal, Marc Benioff from Salesforce. Heavy hitters.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, Peter Thiel from PayPal, Marc Benioff from Salesforce. Heavy hitters.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company is backed by some heavy hitters in the tech industry, including Peter Thiel, co-founder of PayPal and Marc Benioff, the chief executive of Salesforce.com

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, if this really works, it could be a game-changer for ocean health.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, if this really works, it could be a game-changer for ocean health.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It really could be.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It really could be.
